history: The Great Pyramid of Giza is the oldest and largest of the three pyramids at Giza. It was built for the Pharaoh Khufu around 2560 BC. The pyramids were constructed as tombs for the Pharaohs and were part of a larger complex that included temples and smaller pyramids. The construction of the pyramids involved thousands of workers and sophisticated engineering techniques. The Pyramids of Giza are one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World.
Ecological Relevance: The Pyramids of Giza are important for their ecological significance as they are located in the desert landscape of Egypt, which has a unique biodiversity adapted to extreme conditions. The pyramids also serve as a habitat for various species of birds and insects.

timeline.Details: Construction of the Great Pyramid of Giza for Pharaoh Khufu begins.
Construction of the Pyramid of Khafre, Khufu's son, begins.
Construction of the Pyramid of Menkaure, Khufu's grandson, begins.
The last pyramid at Giza is built during the reign of Pharaoh Shepseskaf.
Arab writers visit the pyramids and write about their wonder.
European explorers rediscover the pyramids and begin excavation and study.
Restoration and conservation efforts are undertaken to preserve the pyramids for future generations.
The Pyramids of Giza are designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
The Pyramids of Giza remain a significant archaeological and cultural site, attracting millions of visitors each year.
